Peek Under the Hood: The Magic Explained ğŸ”§âœ¨

Curious about what just happened? Letâ€™s lift the hood and see the sophisticated machinery that read_pglyco3_pglycoquant() runs behind the scenes. Spoiler alert: itâ€™s doing a lot of heavy lifting so you donâ€™t have to!

The 8-Step Data Transformation Dance:

  1. Smart File Reading: Reads your data with intelligent column type detectionâ€”no more â€œeverything is a characterâ€ surprises!
  2. Column Cleaning Magic: Extracts clean UniProt accessions from messy â€œProteinsâ€ columns and handles all those pesky formatting inconsistencies.
  3. Protein Inference Intelligence: Runs a sophisticated â€œparsimonyâ€ algorithm to resolve protein assignment ambiguitiesâ€”because biology is complicated, but your data doesnâ€™t have to be!
  4. ğŸ“Š PSM-to-Glycopeptide Aggregation: Intelligently combines PSM-level quantification into meaningful glycopeptide-level measurements.
  5. Sample Information Validation: Cross-checks sample names and ensures everything matches up perfectly.
  6. ğŸ¯ Data Extraction: Carefully extracts variable information and expression matrix while maintaining data integrity.
  7. ğŸ§¬ Glycan Parsing Power: Leverages the amazing glyparse package to parse glycan compositions and structures into proper data types.
  8. Final Assembly: Packages everything into a beautiful, analysis-ready experiment() object.

The result? What used to take hours of custom scripting now happens in seconds, with bulletproof reliability!

Meet the Whole glyread Family!

One function down, but thereâ€™s so much more! glyread is like a Swiss Army knife for glycoproteomics dataâ€”it speaks the language of virtually every major identification and quantification workflow out there. ğŸ”§

ğŸŒŸ The Complete Toolkit:

  • read_byonic_byologic(): The dynamic duo of Byonic identification + Byologic quantification
  • read_byonic_pglycoquant(): Byonicâ€™s precision meets pGlycoQuantâ€™s power
  • read_msfragger(): MSFragger-Glycoâ€™s all-in-one identification and quantification magic
  • read_pglyco3(): Pure pGlyco3 with its built-in quantification capabilities
  • read_pglyco3_pglycoquant(): The workflow we just exploredâ€”pGlyco3 + pGlycoQuant perfection
  • read_glyco_decipher(): Glyco-Decipherâ€™s identification and label-free quantification
  • read_strucgp(): StrucGPâ€™s identification

Coming Soon to a Package Near You: Weâ€™re actively working on supporting GPQuest, GlycanFinder and other exciting tools. The glycoproteomics software landscape is evolving rapidly, and glyread is evolving right alongside it! ğŸš€

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: No matter which workflow you choose, you can expect the same consistent, clean data format on the other side. Itâ€™s like having a universal remote for your glycoproteomics data!

The Universal Data Language: Consistent Columns Across All Functions

Hereâ€™s the beautiful part: no matter which glyread function you use, youâ€™ll always get the same consistent, predictable data structure. Itâ€™s like having a universal translator that ensures everyone speaks the same language!

ğŸ·ï¸ Your Variable Information Columns - The Standard Cast:

  • peptide ğŸ§¬: The peptide sequence (character) - your proteinâ€™s building blocks
  • peptide_site: Glycosylation site on the peptide (integer) - where the magic happens
  • protein ğŸ·ï¸: UniProt accession (character) - your proteinâ€™s official ID card
  • protein_site ğŸ¯: Glycosylation site on the protein (integer) - the full-length coordinates
  • gene ğŸ§¬: Gene symbol (character) - the genetic blueprint behind it all
  • glycan_composition: A glyrepr::glycan_composition() object - whatâ€™s in your glycan
  • glycan_structure: A glyrepr::glycan_structure() object - how itâ€™s all connected

ğŸ¯ Special Note on Those Last Two: The glycan_composition and glycan_structure columns arenâ€™t just plain textâ€”theyâ€™re sophisticated data types from the amazing glyrepr package. Think of them as smart objects that know how to do glycan math!

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: Getting familiar with glyrepr objects is absolutely worth the investment. They unlock a whole world of glycan analysis capabilities that would be impossible with plain text. Trust us on this one!
